Ceramic Network

Account Management in Ceramic: The Evolution of 3ID

A useful way to think about the DID standard is as a mechanism to bootstrap trust in an identifier. Implementers can define DID Methods that define how to resolve a DID Document from a DID URL. The most widely used DID method today is the Key DID. This method is

A useful way to think about the DID standard is as a mechanism to bootstrap trust in an identifier. Implementers can define DID Methods that define how to resolve a DID Document from a DID URL. The most widely used DID method today is the Key DID.

This method is extremely simple and doesn‚Äôt have some of the more advanced features, such as key rotation, that the DID standard enables. However, there are still big challenges with using DIDs. Privacy being a big one. A wide range of different DID methods that are not compatible is another. This article explores how to build a DID method that is both composable (i.e. it builds on existing DID methods) while also adding privacy.

3ID and Its Limitations

While Ceramic supports multiple different DID methods, 3ID is the main DID method that leverages the network directly. 3ID has gone through two iterations so far. Let‚Äôs take a brief look at them, their limitations, and consider potential future iterations.

The Static 3IDv0

The first iteration of 3ID kept things super simple and worked similarly to a Key DID in that it was immutable. However, it added some flexibility by allowing the use of a variety of different key types in one DID document. For example, a secp256k1 key for signature verification and a x25519 key for receiving encrypted messages. These keys were simply stored in an IPLD object, the CID of which is used as the DID identifier. To resolve a 3IDv0 one simply needs to resolve the IPLD object from its CID, e.g. using IPFS.

The main limitation of 3IDv0 was that it was not possible to do any sort of key rotation. Once the DID is created the public keys provided up front are the keys for this DID forever.

More Flexibility With 3IDv1

The first version of 3ID was designed to enable key rotation and multi-account identity. By using the built-in conflict resolution of Ceramic‚Äôs streams, updating the DID document of a 3ID became straight forward. In this case, a Tile stream type represented the 3ID by storing the public keys in the JSON content of the Tile document. The StreamID of the Tile is then used as the DID identifier. By combining this updatable 3ID with another Ceramic stream type, caip10-links, multiple wallet accounts from different blockchains could be linked to a single 3ID.

While 3IDv1 is more flexible than its predecessor, there are still some significant limitations, primarily around privacy. All verification methods (e.g. public keys) in the DID document are public. There is no way to add a verification method that is unknown to the public observer. Furthermore, the caip10-links necessitated doxxing of the wallet account, creating a permanent link between the account and the 3ID, that even if removed would leave a trace in the caip10-link event log. Finally, UX for actually using a 3IDv1 was not optimal because the keys referenced in the DID Document were long lived. This led to weak security in a browser context and the reliance on an iframe for key management.

Desired Properties of 3IDv2

One of the most difficult things to achieve in a publicly verifiable, permissionless system is privacy. This is true for blockchains, and it‚Äôs also true for data networks like Ceramic. In blockchains, zero-knowledge proofs are being utilized to provide various sorts of privacy enhancements. Could the 3ID DID method utilize zkp and other techniques to achieve greater privacy as well? First, let‚Äôs start by defining what functionality would be desired in a privacy-focused 3ID:

Ability to add and remove verification methods without publicly disclosing their public keys Selective disclosure of verification methods Ability to generate a signature issued by the 3ID without revealing which verification method was invoked Ability to privately graft (i.e. upgrade) existing DIDs to a 3ID (e.g. a caip10-link but private) Selective disclosure of grafted DIDs Primitives for Composable Identity

Let‚Äôs have a look at what primitives we have available to us, or can construct, in order to achieve the properties described above.

Generative DID Methods

A generative DID method can be defined as a DID where the DID Document can be statically generated from the DID URL. This means that there is no need to look up state from a blockchain or do any other sort of network requests. It also means that it‚Äôs not possible to update or remove the DID Document since it is deterministically generated from the DID URL. There are two prominent examples of generative DID methods:

DID Key - every DID URL is a public key with an associated multicode to uniquely identify the key type. In order to generate the DID Document, the public key is simply translated into the appropriate verification method.

DID PKH - short for public key hash, this method essentially makes all blockchain accounts into DIDs. This is achieved by relying on the CAIP-10 account ID standard to identify a specific account on a specific blockchain. The DID URL gets translated to the DID Document using the special blockchain account verification method, which also relies on CAIP-10.

The stream type caip10-link in Ceramic was created before DID PKH existed in order to have a simple stream type controlled by a blockchain account. This functionality can now easily be replaced by any stream type, such as Tile Document or Model Instance Document by using DID PKH.

Object-Capabilities

Signing every data transaction with your DID PKH (e.g. your crypto wallet) makes for less than ideal UX. In order to address this problem, object-capabilities (OCAP) and session keys can be used. The article on CACAO explains how this works in detail, but for context let‚Äôs have a look at how OCAPs can be used.

A session key (DID Key) is randomly generated An authorization message (e.g. SIWE) is generated which contains the DID Key URL and an array of resources being authorized A signature request over this message is sent to the wallet (DID PKH) The message + signature can now be used as an OCAP, that together with the session key, can be used to invoke actions on the authorized resources

Important to note that these OCAPs can also be chained, e.g. Key A ‚Üí Key B ‚Üí Key C, where ‚Üí implies a delegation.

Revocation Registry

Delegation using capabilities is powerful, but we don‚Äôt necessarily want delegations to be valid forever. A possible mitigation is to add an expiry time to the capability as it is issued. Time based revocation is simple but still quite limited and in the case of a compromised key, damage can still be caused before the capability expires. We need a way to check if a particular capability has been revoked by the issuer. Ideally without leaking information about which capabilities have existed over time‚Äîhere a revocation registry can be useful. The capability itself can include a caveat that states that it is only valid if and only if the capability has not been added to the revocation registry.

On Ceramic the revocation registry could be implemented as follows:

An event stream is created where revocation events can be published The revocation event is a multihash of the CID of the capability (an extra hash is added for privacy) Once a revocation event has been anchored it is considered valid and is enforceable starting from the anchor timestamp When a capability is issued it contains a caveat that references the revocation registry using its StreamID When the capability is verified, the revocation registry must be loaded from the Ceramic network; if the capability was revoked before it was invoked it is considered invalid

The lookup time of this revocation registry would be O(n). However, a Ceramic node could build a merkle tree where OCAP hashes are keys and revocation times are values to reduce lookup time to O(log n). In theory this could also make the revocations verifiable on-chain.

Private Capability Invocation

When a capability is invoked to perform some action it will generally be publicly disclosed. Up until the point of invocation it can be kept in secret, but if we want our system to remain publicly verifiable an observer must be able to validate the full delegation chain‚Äîfrom the owner of the resource to the key that performed the invocation. A keen reader might, however, realize that we don‚Äôt actually need to disclose the delegation chain if we use a ZKP to hide certain information.

publicInputs = (rootDID, sessionKey, ocapHashes, resources, actions)

privateInputs = (ocapChain)

The ZKP from above can be verified to ensure that the session key is indeed authorized to take certain actions on the given resources. The revocation registry can be referenced to make sure none of the capabilities are revoked since the ocapHashes are part of the public input.

Note that by including the ocapHashes in the public input some metadata is leaked. An observer will be able to see which capabilities have been frequently used, but they won‚Äôt learn anything about the content of the capability. A possible improvement could be to include the entire revocation registry stream in the public input. An outside observer could simply compare the included registry with a registry loaded locally. As long as the action performed by the invoker was anchored before any change to the registry was anchored the entire capability chain could still be considered valid. This means of course that the ZKP would need to be regenerated every time the revocation registry is updated.

3IDv2: Composable Identity

Combining the primitives above, we can create a composable DID method where verification methods can be added privately using capabilities and revoked using the revocation registry. Similarly to 3IDv0 the first verification method would be added to the initial (public) state of the DID document. After this point, adding a verification method is actually done by using a capability that gives the delegate DID full control to take any action on behalf of the 3ID.

A cool feature is that the revocation registry includes timestamp information (from Ceramic anchors) so that we can see when revocations happen. This makes it easy to validate signatures done in the past, since we can see that the signature was done by the verification method before it was revoked. However, in the case of a delegation chain this might not be enough. Imagine we have Key A delegating to Key B at time T0; then at time T1, Key A gets revoked. From the perspective of the 3ID, Key B should still be valid since it was added by a verification method that was valid at the time. In order to solve this dilemma we can simply add a timestamp for when Key B was added in the revocation registry. This would allow us to keep using Key B even if Key A is revoked.

Grafting DIDs

There is a need to publicly or privately link existing DIDs, such as PKH DIDs, to a 3ID. This can now be done rather simply in Ceramic by creating a deterministic stream that is controlled by the DID in question and include an attestation that this DID is grafted to a particular 3ID. The attestation could be public or encrypted. If it is encrypted it could be selectively disclosed to any third party. For example, to check if an ethereum address (PKH DID) has been grafted to a 3ID, one would simply load the Ceramic stream and check the content of the resolved document. For a private link, a decryption key for the encrypted link would also be required to read to which DID the link points to.

Implementation

An implementation of 3IDv2 might seem daunting at first. It‚Äôs worth noting that it can be done in stages, since each primitive builds upon the previous ones. A prototype could easily be built with only support for capabilities for adding new verification methods. The revocation registry could be built after adding the ability to actually do proper key management and would result in a usable version of the system. Finally, private capability invocation could be added on top, providing a layer of privacy when actually using the identity.

16:36 • 2 months ago

Friday, 07. October 2022

The Engine Room

Working on our digital resilience: video conferencing tools

Earlier this year we started a new project to examine and strengthen our digital resilience. In this blog post, we‚Äôre sharing some reflections about the new tools our team is testing out! The post Working on our digital resilience: video conferencing tools first appeared on The Engine Room.

Earlier this year we started a new project to examine and strengthen our digital resilience. Through this work we hope to further integrate social justice principles into our tech choices and practices and deepen our capacity to support our partners 

After conducting a deeper needs assessment within the team, the first set of changes we made focused on our video conferencing infrastructure. In this blog post, we‚Äôre sharing some reflections about the new tools our team is testing out and how our experience has been so far.

We are using the term ‚Äúdigital resilience‚Äù to refer to a set of practices that support the ability of an organisation to protect itself from ‚Äî and respond to ‚Äî digital security threats, to ensure the wellbeing of its members/individuals, and to adopt infrastructures that respond to the ever-changing needs and contexts of the organisation and its members.

Deciding which video conferencing tools fit our needs and values

At The Engine Room, we aim for a justice-based approach to our technical choices. This means we prioritise choosing technology solutions that intentionally weave anti-oppression strategies into all stages of their creation, maintenance and uptake. As a remote organisation, video conferencing is integral to our day-to-day operations. After conducting a deeper needs assessment within the team, it became clear that adopting tools that are privacy-respecting and strengthen our organisational security was a priority for us. For this reason, we decided to set up our own instances of BigBlueButton (BBB) and Jitsi Meet. Both tools are encrypted, open source, and incorporate privacy by design. 

BigBlueButton (BBB)

BigBlueButton is an open source online learning and video conferencing platform.All traffic from the users‚Äô web browsers to the server goes over standard security protocols when audio, video or screens are being shared.

BBB is designed specifically for educational applications, with features like whiteboards, break-out rooms, and polling. It also integrates with various learning management systems (e.g. Canvas, Moodle). Everything happens in users‚Äô web browsers, so there‚Äôs no need for any additional software.BigBlueButton users don‚Äôt need to create an account to join a call: all they need is the meeting link, which can be opened with a browser. Access to meetings can be limited through a code and joining the room can be dependent on moderator approval.

To use all the functionalities of the tool it is necessary to have a server to install it on. BBB‚Äôs website offers the possibility of creating an account to access a ‚Äúdemo‚Äù version of the tool. Using this version you can make calls of up to 60 minutes.

Jitsi Meet

Jitsi Meet (also referred to as meet.jit.si) is a free and open source video conference service maintained by parent company 8√ó8. By default, Jitsi Meet provides transport-layer encryption between the browser and the Jitsi Meet server of your choice; an end-to-end encryption feature is also available.

Jitsi Meet users don‚Äôt need to create an account to join a call: all they need is the meeting link, which can be opened with a browser or through Jitsi‚Äôs mobile app.

Meetings can also be password-protected.

Jitsi Meet offers the option of self-hosting and there is a public version of the tool for free use.

Some of the factors that we took into account while selecting video conferencing tools are included in the list below (which takes inspiration from many resources, such as this ‚ÄúGuide to Secure Group Chat and Conferencing Tools‚Äù): 

Maturity and maintenance: We took into account how mature the platforms are, including the amount of time they‚Äôve been running for and whether or not they are still being actively developed. We also considered the existence of active communities of developers and users for both tools. Privacy: A variety of factors went into consideration: whether or not user data is shared or sold to third parties, if the tools provide encryption (and what type of encryption: end-to-end or to-server), if it‚Äôs possible to self-host, what data is stored on platforms‚Äô servers and what data platforms‚Äô owners have access to, if users need to install a dedicated app or software and what data this app or software would have access to. Reputation: We prioritised tools that are used and respected by social justice organisations and peers we work with, as well as recommended by security experts.  Ownership: We considered whether tools were open source and if the companies provided the source code openly, as well as the history of development and ownership of the platform and potential security challenges (including how owners and developers reacted to those challenges). Features and affordances: We mapped the platforms according to how well their features would respond to our needs: easiness to connect to these platforms, usage of tools for internal and external calls and more.  Associated costs: We also considered the costs related to each of the tools, including potential subscription fees, learning and implementing, possible IT support needed and hosting costs A brief overview of our experience so far

Hosting and infrastructure details
‚Äì For BigBlueButton, we hired Maadix‚Äòs hosting service, who are maintaining both the tool and the servers where it‚Äôs hosted. We use a version customised by Maadix with performance and privacy improvements.
‚Äì For Jitsi Meet, we are using the pre-installed stable version that Greenhost ‚Äì with whom we have been already working ‚Äì offers to their clients.

After implementation, we asked our team to use BigBlueButton and Jitsi Meet as much as possible. After two months of piloting the tools, we conducted an internal survey and received mostly positive feedback‚Äîoverall the team appreciated using tools that are aligned with our organisational values. We also identified areas for improvement, which we will work on over the next few months, including user friendliness and video instability. 

It‚Äôs important to note that while we try to default to using our own internal platforms, there are occasions where we have a need for features that these platforms do not yet have. For example, we often use webinar registration pages and waiting rooms to ensure that our community calls are safe for participants; however, BigBlueButton and Jitsi Meet do not currently possess these features. Additionally, although both platforms aim to be low resource, they often struggle in low bandwidth situations. Lastly, there‚Äôs the learning curve of the team for adapting new tools. We often crave for the familiar when it‚Äôs not immediately clear how to perform a certain task. We recognize that adapting to the workflow of these tools will take time as is the case with most technological changes.

Here is a summary of some of the benefits and challenges of installing and maintaining these tools on our own servers. 

Advantages Authonomy: More control over the tools we use, since we are responsible for the installation and can check all code that runs in the application. Values: Tools that are aligned with our values and principles. Transparency: Transparency of the open software code‚Äîwe can inspect every line of code used to build the tools. Security:  With open source tools, more people are inspecting the code, which enables more issues to be found ‚Äì and fixed. Vulnerabilities are fixed much faster and updates are more frequent.  Cost: Open-source software is very often free or cheaper than proprietary software. Therefore, we save on licensing and maintenance fees.  Open source ecosystem: We are contributing to a community of developers committed to making the internet a fairer place. Customisation and Flexibility: Using services customised for our use and having exclusive domains. Challenges Resources: Self-hosted tools require more maintenance time and investment in servers. Tech expertise: Self-hosted tools require knowledge and availability (internal or external) to troubleshoot issues the team or our partners experience. Documentation: Using tools that are less widespread or familiar demands an effort to produce technical and user-facing documentation. For example, we developed internal user guides for both platforms containing FAQs, and we also created an external guide that explains our decisions behind specific platform use in community calls. Adapting to new tools: Functionality is not always the same between tools and even when it is, the user experience may differ. Adopting new tools can take time (as we wrote in this blog post) and can impact the day-to-day work of the organisation. Stability and availability: Ensuring that self-hosted tools are stable and have high availability (or the ability of a system to operate continuously without failing) is a challenge. Constant monitoring,  maintenance, and server redundancy (storing information in more than one server) are steps required to make sure information can be restored in case of problems.

This overview represents a snapshot of where we currently are in our journey with these tools: these observations will likely evolve and change over time, as we work on this project and mature our own digital resilience practices.

Next steps

During this process, we were reminded of how adopting free and open-source software tools (and self-hosting them!) is a process that takes quite some time and planning, but that ultimately contributes greatly to our digital resilience. Over the next months, we will continue to work on our video conferencing tools, including improving on the tools‚Äô overall performance and stability, refining user documentation and addressing connectivity issues.

If your organisation is interested in going through a similar process, we‚Äôd be happy to support you (even if your end result is different!). Schedule a call with us!

Image by Chris Montgomery via Unsplash.

The post Working on our digital resilience: video conferencing tools first appeared on The Engine Room.
06:16 • 2 months ago

Thursday, 06. October 2022

Centre Consortium

Circle and Industry Leaders Have Built the First Decentralized Identity Proof-of-Concept for Crypto Finance using Centre Verite Credentials

 

 

18:31 • 2 months ago

We Are Open co-op

How to Unf*ck Your Organisation

Organisational strategy and architecture for n00bs ‚ÄúThe purpose of an organisation is to enable common people to do uncommon things.‚Äù (Peter Drucker) WAO works with complex, multinational clients as well as smaller groups containing just a handful of people. While every organisation is different, we‚Äôve noticed things in common that we often have to help them untangle. CC BY WAO We
Organisational strategy and architecture for n00bs
‚ÄúThe purpose of an organisation is to enable common people to do uncommon things.‚Äù (Peter Drucker)

WAO works with complex, multinational clients as well as smaller groups containing just a handful of people. While every organisation is different, we‚Äôve noticed things in common that we often have to help them untangle.

CC BY WAO

We‚Äôve put together an email-based course to help forward-thinking people in senior roles who might need a bit of help and orientation. We‚Äôve broken things down into actionable steps based on the resources found at our Learn with WAO site, giving you enough direction and inspiration to get started transforming your organisation for the better!

üëâ Sign up here üëà

Here‚Äôs what to expect

The course arrives in your inbox by email. The only signing up you have to do is right at the beginning, when you enter your email address and your first name. We‚Äôll only use your data to keep you informed about this course, in accordance with our privacy policy.

0. Intro‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääexplaining and introducing the course

1. Grokking your context‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääyou can‚Äôt plan a route to where you‚Äôre going unless you know where you‚Äôre at!

2. Developing a mental model‚Ää‚Äî‚Äädeveloping your own metaphors to understand the change(s) you‚Äôre trying to make.

3. Prioritising all the things‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääfiguring out what‚Äôs most important is a multi-faceted problem that requires facilitated thinking

4. Spotting potential problems‚Ää‚Äî‚Äälet‚Äôs remove blockers before they become a problem, and figure out how to deal with them if they do.

5. Rubber hits the road‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääputting it all together and running a retrospective

This is the first version of How to Unf*ck Your Organisation, which will improve with your feedback. So please feel free to hit ‚Äòreply‚Äô at any time and get a response by a real, live, human being!

üëâ Sign up here üëà

How often will I receive emails?

We‚Äôve put together a a range of email courses over the past couple of years, and others we run have varied email delivery frequencies. So we thought we‚Äôd ask on the different networks in whichwe‚Äôre active to find out what people prefer.

Here‚Äôs the results of our not-incredibly-scientific polling:

We ran the poll in Slack using emoji voting, which means people can see others‚Äô votes before they cast theirs‚Ää‚Äî‚Äädid that skew responses? ü§î (CC BY WAO)

As you can see from the above chart, although there‚Äôs some support for monthly, it‚Äôs weekly email deliveries that got the most votes. So that‚Äôs what we‚Äôre going to do!

üëâ Sign up here üëà

How much does this cost?

The great thing about this course is not only is it free and links to free resources, but you can receive an awesome badge at the end of it. It‚Äôs literally full of win.

If you think it looks like we typed in ‚Äústormtroopers in the style of Keith Haring‚Äù into an AI art generator and put the result into a wobbly circle, then you‚Äôd be absolutely correct (CC BY WAO)

While the course is free, it‚Äôs not cheap, so if you‚Äôd like to help support our efforts please make a one-off or recurring donation via Open Collective.

https://opencollective.com/weareopen

How to Unf*ck Your Organisation was originally published in We Are Open Co-op on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

13:28 • 2 months ago

Digital Identity NZ

2022 Executive Council nominations now open

There is now an opportunity to put yourself forward or nominate someone else for a role on the Digital Identity NZ Executive Council. The post 2022 Executive Council nominations now open appeared first on Digital Identity New Zealand.

In December 2019, members elected the first Digital Identity NZ Executive Council. The Council is the governing group for the association; providing guidance and direction as we navigate the developing world of digital identity in Aotearoa. Each Council member is elected for a two-year term, with elections held annually and results notified at the Annual Meeting in December. So, as we approach the end of the year it is time for us to call for nominations for the Council seats coming up for re-election.

Executive Council Nominations  

There is now an opportunity to put yourself forward or nominate someone else for a role on the Digital Identity NZ Executive Council. This year we have vacancies for the following positions: 

Corporate‚ÄØ- Major (2‚ÄØpositions)  Corporate ‚Äì Other (1 positions)  SME & Start-up (2‚ÄØposition) 

The nominees for the above positions must be from a Digital Identity NZ member organisation and be from the same Digital Identity NZ Membership Group that they are to represent on the Executive Council. 

All nominations must be entered into the online form here‚ÄØby 5pm, Thursday 27 October 2022.

Digital Identity NZExecutive Council roles and responsibilities include:

Direct and supervise the business and affairs of Digital Identity NZ  Attend monthly Executive Council meetings, usually two‚ÄØhours in duration (video conferencing available)  Represent Digital Identity NZ at industry events and as part of‚ÄØdelegations  Assist with managing and securing members of Digital Identity NZ  Participate in Digital Identity NZ working groups and projects  Where agreed by the Executive Council, act as a spokesperson for Digital Identity NZ on particular issues relating to working groups or projects  Be a vocal advocate of Digital Identity NZ 

Online Voting

Voting will take place online in advance of the meeting. The results will be announced at the Annual Meeting. Please see the Charter ‚ÄØfor an outline of Executive Council Membership and election process. Each organisation has one vote that is allocated to the primary contact of the member organisation.

Meet the candidate

Save the date. We will be holding a virtual ‚Äòmeet the candidate‚Äô meeting at 12pm on 3 Nov 2022.

Annual Meeting Details

The Annual Meeting is scheduled for 3.00pm on Thursday 1 December 2022 and is to be held via Zoom. Register for the event here.‚ÄØ

Notices and Remits

If you wish to propose any notices or motions to be considered at the Annual Meeting, please send them to elections@digitalidentity.nz‚ÄØby 5pm, Thursday 10 November 2022.    

Key Dates:

Now: Call for Nominations for Executive Council representatives issued to Members  27 October: Deadline for nominations to be received  3 November: Save the date! Meet the candidate online event.  7 November: List of nominees to be issued to Digital Identity voting members‚ÄØand electronic voting commences  17 November: Any proposed notices, motions, or remits to be advised to Digital Identity NZ  1‚ÄØDecember: Annual Meeting, results of online voting announced. 

Background:

From the beginning we have asked that you consider electing a diverse group of members who reflect the diversity of the community we seek to support. We ask that you do so again this year.‚ÄØ The power of that diversity continues to shine through in the new working groups this year, especially as we consider the importance of Te Tiriti, equity and inclusion in a well-functioning digital identity ecosystem.

The Council has identified a number of areas where diversity, as well as expertise in the digital identity space, might help us better serve the community. Nominations from those organisations involved in kaupapa MƒÅori, civil liberties and business and service sectors are especially encouraged. We also encourage suggestions from young people within your organisations, as the viewpoint of young people is extremely essential and relevant to the work we perform. As an NZTech Association, Digital Identity NZ adopts its Board Diversity and Inclusion Policy which‚ÄØyou can read‚ÄØhere.

Once elected in December, one of the first responsibilities of the new Council will be to elect a new chair for the EC Council or consider re-electing the current chair. The current chair is Paul Platen (SSS ‚Äì Security Specialists), supported by deputy chair (and past-chair) Ben Tairea (ƒÄhau). Both are excellent kaiƒÅrahi (guides/counsellors/leaders) currently and serving their terms on the Executive Council through to the end of 2023. 

2023 is set to be another pivotal year for digital identity with the delayed introduction of the Digital Identity Bill and further development of the ecosystem. We look forward to stellar nominations to identify, explore and pursue the best opportunities for Digital Identity NZ to make a positive difference for people in 2023 and beyond.

The post 2022 Executive Council nominations now open appeared first on Digital Identity New Zealand.

02:00 • 2 months ago

Blockchain Commons

2022 Q3 Blockchain Commons Report

It‚Äôs been another busy quarter at Blockchain Commons, with a focus on new foundations, created in coordination with our community. Major Works Firm Foundations: Hello to the Identity Community Gordian Envelope MVA Algorithm Suite Collaborative Seed Recovery CSR Use Cases Community Events: Silicon Salon 2 RWOT11 Congrats to DIDs New & Updated Projects: Beancount SpotBit Advocacy: Law & Advoc

It‚Äôs been another busy quarter at Blockchain Commons, with a focus on new foundations, created in coordination with our community.

Major Works

Firm Foundations:

Hello to the Identity Community Gordian Envelope MVA Algorithm Suite Collaborative Seed Recovery CSR Use Cases

Community Events:

Silicon Salon 2 RWOT11 Congrats to DIDs

New & Updated Projects:

Beancount SpotBit

Advocacy:

Law & Advocacy Repo Private Key Disclosure

Web Site Updates:

Vision Page About Page Projects Page

Doc Updates:

Revised Gordian Page New Test Vectors Read More Firm Foundations

Much of our work in Q3 has been forward-thinking, focused on creating the next generation of specifications for blockchain interoperability.

Hello to the Identity Community. Being able to create the next generation of specifications depends on having a wide-spanning community, and we‚Äôve been thrilled to see the Blockchain Commons community continue to grow. That includes not just cryptocurrency nowadays, but also digital identity thanks to sustaining sponsor Proxy. We also reached out to more digital-identity companies at this year‚Äôs Rebooting the Web of Trust event, and hope to see that pay out in the near future.

Gordian Envelope. Our specification work is intended to build firm foundations. Our newest foundational work of this sort has been on Gordian Envelope, a new sort of ‚ÄúSmart Container‚Äù that can be used to hold secrets and metadata of an arbitrary size and that can be opened by a variety of ‚Äúpermits‚Äù, including SSKR shares and public-key cryptography keypairs. Extensive docs are now available as part of our BCSwiftSecureCompanents package. Also see our Gordian Envelope videos on our YouTube channel.

MVA Algorithm Suite. The appendix of the Gordian Envelope docs contains our first MVA ALgorithm Suite. This refers to the algorithmic suite we‚Äôve decided to use in our Minimal Viable Architecture: effectively a future-proofed Minimal Viable Product. It overviews current cryptographic algorithms and discusses our decisions about which to use. Gordian Envelope uses BLAKE3, IETF ChaChaPoly, the secp256k1 curve, and more. Our Appendix talks about why we think they‚Äôre the best practices for this project.

Collaborative Seed Recovery. This new foundational work is largely in service to Collaborative Seed Recovery (CSR): we intend it to add independence, resilience, and openness to seed storage by allowing digital-asset holders to shard their seed and then store it with a variety of different steward services, making recovery painless and resilient. We are currently working with a companies such as Bitmark, Foundation, and Proxy in regular biweekly meetings to make CSR a reality this fall. For more, please see our CSR Overview. Our Gordian Envelope videos also lay out the whole foundation, so take a look at the combined CSR playlist.

CSR Use Cases. Why is CSR needed? We‚Äôve written several sequences of progressive use cases in a preliminary document that discusses options both for CSR and its 2023 successor, Collaborative Key Management (CKM). It covers everything from simple protection of keys to future possibilities where no one actually holds a complete seed, despite its keys being in active use.

Community Events

Preventing vendor lock-in via interoperability has been a Blockchain Commons goal from the beginning, but that requires bringing together multiple parties to buy into interoperable specifications. The growth of Blockchain Commons‚Äô community of developers, sponsors, and other interested parties in 2022 has truly made that possible, with those parties coming together in community events such as the biweekly CSR meetings and others.

Silicon Salon 2. Our other ongoing get-together this year has been the Silicon Salon, where we‚Äôve facilitated wallet makers and semiconductor makers talking about the creation of the next generation of silicon design that is specialized for cryptography. Our second Silicon Salon was held on September 14th. Presenters included Bunnie Studios, Cramium Labs, Proxy Labs, Foundation, and the VLS team.

RWOT11. Blockchain Commons got its start with Rebooting the Web of Trust, where Christopher Allen first brought community members together to support the future of decentralized and self-sovereign technologies. Unfortunately, Rebooting the Web of Trust went on hiatus shortly after the foundation of Blockchain Commons, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but it was back this September.

Blockchain Commons submitted two papers for RWOT11, to bring some of our topics into the conversation in the Netherlands: an introduction to CSR and Elision, Redaction, and Non-Correlation in Smart Documents. The elision topic paper led to a discussion of Selection Disclosure that we‚Äôre looking forward to finishing in the coming months. We also participated in an article on Identity Threats, which returns to some of our early identity work in the field!

Congrats to DIDs. We can‚Äôt talk about RWOT without congratulating everyone who worked on turning DIDs into a standard. This has been a long-running goal for both RWOT and Blockchain Commons, so we were thrilled to see DIDs become a W3C Recommendation this July.

New & Updated Projects

We have also continued work on some of our smaller projects:

Beancount. Beancount is a simple program that allows double-entry accounting from text files. Because of its textual foundation, it‚Äôs very convenient to use in conjunction with command-line Bitcoin tools. As it happens, this type of tool is also crucial to Bitcoin because of regulatory decisions in the US treating Bitcoin as property, not currency, meaning that capital gains need to be calculated for every transaction(!). This requires careful accounting of your Bitcoin, and to support that, we‚Äôve updated our SpotBit server to also include a script called beancounter.py that will take a descriptor, look up historical prices via SpotBit, and thus provide all of the data an accountant will need to properly report Bitcoin purchases, sales, and usages. We‚Äôve iterated the software a few times during the quarter, and think we might have a final version; watch for some documentation on the process in the coming quarter.

SpotBit. We‚Äôve actually had a few recent updates to SpotBit, primarily to improve the look, feel, and design of its webpages. Thanks to 2022 interns who supported in this upgrade.

Advocacy

The work that Blockchain Commons does on specifications, leading to libraries and reference apps, is bottom-up: we work with developers to incorporate specifications that meet our vision of independence, privacy, resilience, and openness. However, we also do top-down work, where we advocate for this vision to lawmakers, agencies, and other organizations.

Law & Advocacy Repo. To better highlight this work, which was also well-supported by our 2022 interns, we‚Äôve added a Law & Advocacy repo to GitHub, to report out much of our work. It includes a list of Terminology & Definitions produced by this year‚Äôs interns, and links to other work.

Private Key Disclosure. That work includes our new article advocating for protection for private keys in courts, which was published by Bitcoin Magazine. In recent years, courts have begun to request private keys as part of pre-trial discovery motions. It‚Äôs dangerous and unnecessary and it needs to end, as is now being considered in Wyoming, where Christopher Allen continues to give regular testimony. Fortunately, the proposed law in Wyoming to protect private keys from disclosure has recently passed a select committee and moved on to others. It still has a ways to go though!

Web Site Updates

Blockchain Commons‚Äô third birthday passed without mention this Spring. But, that span of time since our foundation is probably why we‚Äôve been doing a bit of work cleaning up our web presence, to make sure it accurately reflects where we are today!

About Page. Didn‚Äôt even know that Blockchain Commons had a birthday? It‚Äôs referenced on our brand-new About Page which also highlights our three principals: Founder & Executive Director Christopher Allen; Lead Researcher Wolf McNally; and Lead Tech Writer Shannon Appelcline.

Vision Page. We‚Äôve long known the goal of Blockchain Commons: to make it possible for people to control their own assets and information on the internet, using the decentralized power of blockchain technology. We slightly revised how we write about that vision this quarter. Our newest statement combines two previous statements to say:

‚ÄúBlockchain Commons advocates for the creation of open, interoperable, secure & compassionate digital infrastructure to enable people to control their own digital destiny and to maintain their human dignity online.‚Äù

Projects Page. You may also want to take a look at our updated Projects Page. We‚Äôve done a lot of different work over the last three and a half years. Our updated projects page now highlights what we consider most important to our vision, beginning with the Gordian System.

Airgapped Community. Though we continue to believe strongly in partitioning services to encourage the Gordian Principles of independence, privacy, resilience, and openness, that‚Äôs today much bigger than the airgaps that we were considering several years ago. As a result, we‚Äôve transformed the Airgapped Wallet Community into the Gordian Developer Community. We choose the name ‚ÄúGordian Developer Community‚Äù for this update because the Gordian System today incorporates all of our developer-focused work, from Principles and Architecture to Specifications and Libraries, plus the Apps that demonstrate them. We look forward to talking with airgapped-wallet developers and those working on other partitioning techniques alike!

Doc Updates

As part of our web updating, we‚Äôve also done some work on our docs.

Revised Gordian Page. How does the whole Gordian system fit together, from our air-gap and tor-gap overview to specifications such as Gordian Envelope? Our updated Gordian page walks through the whole system from top to bottom, including new pages on topics such as the Gordian Architecture and Gordian Architecture Roles

New Test Vectors. We‚Äôve also produced some new test vectors, to help people who are implementing our specifications. These include SSKR test vectors based on 256-bit seeds and crypto-seed test vectors for both 128-bit and 256-bit seeds.

Final Notes

Thank you as always for your support for Blockchain Commons. In 2022, we have truly become the commons that we imagined. Moving forward, we will continue to build firm foundations with our big focus on the architectural and reference work needed to release CSR by the end of the year.

If you‚Äôre not already a sponsor of our work, you can become one through GitHub. Now that we‚Äôre back from RWOT11 in the Netherlands, we‚Äôre looking forward to continuing to advance our work!

00:00 • 2 months ago

Wednesday, 05. October 2022

We Are Open co-op

Steps to Success when building a Community of Practice

ü§© Convening systems for maturity and development Overview This post outlines different types of work that needs to take place when planning, sustaining, and developing a Community of Practice. It is informed by work that WAO have carried out with Participate around the Keep Badges Weird community over the last 10 months. üìö KBW Case Study The stages outlined below taken from an evolut
ü§© Convening systems for maturity and development Overview

This post outlines different types of work that needs to take place when planning, sustaining, and developing a Community of Practice. It is informed by work that WAO have carried out with Participate around the Keep Badges Weird community over the last 10 months.

üìö KBW Case Study

The stages outlined below taken from an evolution of the work around a maturity model for online, networked communities and systems convening for breaking boundaries. We found that a space flight metaphor resonated more deeply than the previous one we were using, and so we have continued with as our work has developed.

Image CC BY WAO

The above image plots ‚Äòenergy and visibility‚Äô against ‚Äòphases‚Äô through with the community moves. Like rockets, communities need to reach escape velocity to avoid crashing back down to earth. It takes as much energy to sustain and develop communities as it does to initiate them.

Image CC BY WAO

This image uses the work of Etienne and Beverly Wenger-Trayner around systems convening, and maps it against stages of development taken from our space flight metaphor.

We‚Äôll dig into each section in the main detail of the post, but it‚Äôs worth pointing out that all of these types of work are important in their own right. There are certain times at which they are crucially important, but they need to happen in some form at every stage of community development.

Step 1: Gather (aka `Ignition‚Äô) Image CC BY WAO a) Pinpoint your people Members have a safe space to meet and communicate There is an idea of who the community is for Easy onboarding makes it simple to get started b) Do something together There are regular invitations to participate in the community Members can get involved in different activities within the community There are ways of working openly that allow new members to get involved / catch up c) Get people talking Community members meet regularly using agreed channels and tools There are backchannels and watercoolers for varied conversations Members are connecting with people they haven‚Äôt had the chance to before üß∞ Tools & Resources Quick wins to improve your Open Source community‚Äôs Architecture of Participation Emergent community building Defining the Cast Step 2: Dispatch (aka `Liftoff‚Äô) Image CC BY WAO a) Attract new folks New members feel welcomed into the community Core members are motivating others to take part in the community Members regularly share knowledge and experiences external to the community b) Cultivate your identity Members of the community have agreed on guidelines for how to interact with one another (e.g. a Code of Conduct) The needs of community members have been identified The community‚Äôs mission is clear and agreed upon c) Pay attention to who‚Äôs showing up Members adopt common approaches, enabling them to do their work more effectively Members talk about the community to other people in their network The community is meeting members‚Äô needs based on explicit feedback üß∞ Tools & Resources 11 steps to running an online community meeting Community Canvas template Contributor Covenant Step 3: Explore (aka `Orbital Flight‚Äô) Image CC BY WAO a) Create more leaders Moderation responsibilities are shared among a larger group of core members The community has a momentum that is not reliant on one or two people The community has goals that members collaborate on as a whole or in smaller working groups b) Supercharge your leaders Leadership responsibilities and decision-making are distributed throughout the community Members explicitly influence community direction and activities There are open-door activities with people outside of the community (e.g. show and tells, cross-community meetups) c) Celebrate together Milestones relating to the community and its members are celebrated People outside the community advocate for it The community regularly creates outputs used by the wider network üß∞ Tools & Resources Strategic Starfish Sociocracy what? What We Talk About When We Talk About Open Step 4: Systems Change (aka `Space Station‚Äô) Image CC BY WAO a) Connect with power People ask the community how to recognise others in ways that do not depend on competition or artificial scarcity Community members can name relevant power structures Community members know how to both leverage and resist existing power structures b) Nourish leaders Leaders share their tips on networking and leveraging influence Leaders are close enough to their organization to have support, but separate enough to remain free to explore and innovate on their terms Leaders are adept at communicating the value of Open recognition c) Tell the stories The community has resources to help advocates empower and motivate learners The community can help policy makers establish innovative policy Members actively search out and articulate the value they are creating üß∞ Tools & Resources Creating a culture of recognition Audience Ikigai How badges can change the world‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäPart 1: The Two Loops Model for Open Recognition advocacy References

We work openly, and are grateful for the following inspiration:

Community of Practice Maturity Model by Emily Webber (CC BY-NC 4.0) Get Together by Bailey Richardson, Kevin Huynh & Kai Elmer Sotto Systems Convening: A crucial form of leadership for the 21st century by the Social Learning Lab

Steps to Success when building a Community of Practice was originally published in We Are Open Co-op on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

Next Level Supply Chain Podcast with GS1

Reaching Human Potential Through Intelligent Automation

Scientific excellence in the 21st century relies heavily on automated monitoring and quality control techniques. In this episode, we‚Äôre speaking with Silas Adekunle from Reach Industries, an innovative startup that is leveraging computer vision to augment scientists and make labs more efficient in order to tackle global challenges faster.

In this episode, we‚Äôre speaking with Silas Adekunle from Reach Industries, an innovative startup that is leveraging computer vision to augment scientists and make labs more efficient in order to tackle global challenges faster.

14:00 • 2 months ago

The Engine Room

Our new FAQ: key questions about tech and data for social justice organisations

Part of our work at The Engine Room includes helping partners and peers with questions they have around tech and data. Since a lot of organisations come to us with similar concerns, we have compiled some of the key questions we get asked in the following FAQ (Frequently Asked Questions).  The post Our new FAQ: key questions about tech and data for social justice organisations first appeared

This year, with support from Sigrid Rausing Trust, we deepened our offer of support to activists, collectives and movements ‚Äì particularly those who serve marginalised communities ‚Äì that are facing challenges incorporating technologies in their work. 

Through our work, we see that working with tech and data isn‚Äôt a simple process for many social justice organisations and that many of our partners share similar concerns. So we decided to compile some of the key questions we get asked in a new FAQ (Frequently Asked Questions), currently available in English, Spanish and Portuguese (and soon in French). 

In this FAQ, we‚Äôre answering questions such as:

How can organisations start using more tech/data in their work? How can organisations decide which tools to use? What can be done to make sure staff is safe when using tech and data? And many more! Read in English Lee Espa√±ol Leia em Portugu√™s Lisez en Fran√ßais

Get tailored support from our team

In the FAQ, we don‚Äôt go into deep detail in each answer; instead, we point you in a direction to take next and share additional resources. If you have specific questions and/or are interested in figuring out how tech and data can best support your work, reach out to our team! We customise our support based on the specific needs and contexts of each social justice organisation we work with! 

Schedule a call with us!

Image by Patrick Perkins via Unsplash.

The post Our new FAQ: key questions about tech and data for social justice organisations first appeared on The Engine Room.

The post FAQ: Perguntas Frequentes sobre Tecnologia e Dados first appeared on The Engi

Espa√±ol | English | Fran√ßais

Parte de nosso trabalho na The Engine Room inclui ajudar organiza√ß√µes parceiras com d√∫vidas que elas possam ter relacionadas a tecnologia e dados. Como diversos grupos nos procuram com quest√µes parecidas, compilamos no FAQ (perguntas frequentes) a seguir algumas das principais perguntas que recebemos.

Apesar de n√£o entrarmos em muitos detalhes em cada resposta, ao longo do texto tentamos compartilhar orienta√ß√µes de qual dire√ß√£o voc√™ pode tomar em seguida. Confira nosso programa Light-Touch Support se tiver mais perguntas.

Este trabalho foi possibilitado pelo apoio do Sigrid Rausing Trust.

Antes de iniciarmos, o que queremos dizer com dados? E tecnologia? Provavelmente voc√™ est√° usando os dois!

Definimos ‚Äòdados‚Äô como informa√ß√µes que precisam ser processadas, organizadas e estruturadas para que possam ser utilizadas. Em outras palavras, com dados estamos nos referindo √†s informa√ß√µes que voc√™ possui, como os detalhes sobre as comunidades com as quais trabalha, resultados de pesquisas que fez, endere√ßos de e-mail e informa√ß√µes de contato de apoiadores e assim por diante.

Entendemos ‚Äòtecnologia‚Äô como as ferramentas, os sistemas, m√©todos e processos que capitalizam o poder computacional para gerenciar, analisar e comunicar informa√ß√µes. Para isso, quando falamos em tecnologia, queremos dizer ferramentas digitais, em termos gerais. Qualquer coisa, desde plataformas de e-mail e apps de mensagens at√© hosts de sites, plataformas de newsletters por e-mail, CRMs, bancos de dados, processos algor√≠tmicos e mais.

FAQ: perguntas frequentes sobre tecnologia e dados Primeiros passos ‚Äì entendendo a vis√£o geral sobre tecnologia e dados P1: Dever√≠amos buscar usar mais tecnologia/dados em nosso trabalho? P2: Como eu e minha equipe podemos aprender mais sobre tecnologia e como ela √© relevante para o nosso trabalho? Por onde come√ßamos?  P4: Como posso garantir que as ferramentas tecnol√≥gicas e os dados que estamos usando s√£o realmente √∫teis para o nosso trabalho? Tomando decis√µes ‚Äì certificando-se de que os dados e a tecnologia que voc√™ usa est√£o de acordo com seus valores e sua miss√£o P5: Como tomamos decis√µes acerca de adotar novas ferramentas e/ou coletar dados? P6: Minha organiza√ß√£o quer integrar novas tecnologias, mas ainda n√£o encontramos a ferramenta certa. Dever√≠amos criar n√≥s mesmos uma ferramenta? P7: Como posso usar tecnologia/dados se meu acesso √† internet ou √† eletricidade n√£o √© confi√°vel? P8: Como trabalhar com pessoas desenvolvedoras e/ou especialistas em tecnologia? P9: Como fazer para que a colabora√ß√£o online funcione melhor para minha organiza√ß√£o? Seguran√ßa e cuidado em foco P10: Como posso garantir que toda minha equipe est√° usando as ferramentas (ou processos de dados) que escolhemos? P11: O que podemos fazer para manter as pessoas em seguran√ßa quando come√ßarmos a usar diferentes ferramentas tecnol√≥gicas e pr√°ticas de dados? Primeiros passos ‚Äì entendendo a vis√£o geral sobre tecnologia e dados P1: Organiza√ß√µes parceiras parecem estar usando mais tecnologia/dados. Tamb√©m dever√≠amos buscar usar mais tecnologia/dados em nosso trabalho?

A resposta para isso realmente depende do contexto. A tecnologia pode lhe auxiliar a organizar tarefas e opera√ß√µes di√°rias, permitir comunica√ß√£o mais segura, coletar e gerenciar informa√ß√µes, cortar gastos e liberar or√ßamento, entre outras possibilidades. Mas, se usada de maneira ineficaz ou sem estrat√©gia, a tecnologia tamb√©m pode comprometer a sua capacidade de realizar o seu trabalho com seguran√ßa e efic√°cia.

Por exemplo, se sua organiza√ß√£o estiver coletando relatos em primeira m√£o de viola√ß√µes aos direitos humanos em √°reas com pouca conectividade √† internet/rede m√≥vel, a ado√ß√£o de uma ferramenta de coleta de dados que necessite de conex√£o com a internet dificultar√° o seu trabalho e impactar√° negativamente a sua capacidade de cumprir a sua miss√£o.

Se usada sem estrat√©gia, a tecnologia tamb√©m pode lhe expor e expor as pessoas com quem voc√™ trabalha a novas vulnerabilidades e novos riscos. Por exemplo, se voc√™ est√° em um contexto em que a monitora√ß√£o da sociedade civil pelo governo √© comum e est√° usando ferramentas que n√£o protejam suas comunica√ß√µes de maneira adequada, isso pode comprometer o seu trabalho e a sua seguran√ßa.

Para ter certeza de que voc√™ usar√° a tecnologia estrategicamente e com responsabilidade, separe um tempo para pensar a respeito de como implantar uma nova tecnologia ou coletar mais dados poderia fortalecer ou enfraquecer o seu trabalho. Antes de adotar quaisquer novas ferramentas ou plataformas, tente fortalecer a sua capacidade interna, conectar-se com outras organiza√ß√µes que voc√™ respeita.

P2: Como eu e minha equipe podemos aprender mais sobre tecnologia e como ela √© relevante para o nosso trabalho?

Trabalhar para desenvolver a intui√ß√£o t√©cnica da equipe de maneira lenta e incremental, fazendo com que seja uma prioridade para toda a equipe tanto quanto poss√≠vel (em vez de trabalho de uma √∫nica pessoa). Quando o assunto s√£o novas ferramentas e aplica√ß√µes, h√° muita informa√ß√£o online que pode ser tentadora ‚Äì mas pode ser dif√≠cil identificar o que √© relevante para voc√™ e o que n√£o √©.

Nota: algumas das informa√ß√µes que voc√™ vai reunir como parte deste exerc√≠cio de mapeamento podem ser sens√≠veis; antes de come√ßar, garanta que suas notas est√£o armazenadas em um local seguro e s√£o compartilhadas apenas com pessoas que precisam acess√°-las.

Quais ferramentas voc√™ usa atualmente para seu trabalho?  Quais plataformas/ferramentas voc√™ e sua equipe usam para se comunicar? Dentre elas, podem estar e-mail, mensagens instant√¢neas, m√≠dias sociais, SMS e sites, para listar algumas. Como voc√™ armazena e gerencia seus arquivos e documentos? Quais plataformas voc√™ usa? Todos na sua equipe usam as mesmas plataformas? Voc√™ est√° trabalhando em campanhas p√∫blicas ou faz parte de esfor√ßos coletivos com outras organiza√ß√µes? Se sim, quais ferramentas usa para ativismo, organiza√ß√£o e manter a comunidade? Est√° trabalhando com algum banco de dados ou plataforma de pesquisa?

Como voc√™ est√° usando os dados? Que tipo de dados/informa√ß√µes voc√™ coleta ou gera no cotidiano? Pense sobre seus fluxos de trabalho individuais e coletivos e liste os momentos em que voc√™ coleta ou gera dados. Por exemplo, coletar informa√ß√µes de contatos das pessoas que voc√™ entrevistou, conversar por e-mail ou WhatsApp, tomar notas de entrevistas ou reuni√µes ou realizar pesquisas com comunidades. Onde voc√™ armazena os dados? Considere os dados que voc√™ j√° tem e liste todos os lugares onde est√£o (garanta que est√° incluindo todos os lugares remotos ‚Äì e-mails, documentos compartilhados e assim por diante). Onde e como voc√™ compartilha os dados? Pense sobre as vezes em que voc√™ precisa compartilhar os dados: quando isso normalmente acontece, com quem voc√™ compartilha essas informa√ß√µes e quais ferramentas utiliza? Por exemplo, voc√™ pode enviar planilhas ou PDFs por e-mail, compartilhar documentos e atas de reuni√µes pelo Google Docs ou compartilhar senhas atrav√©s de um aplicativo de mensagens.

Essas s√£o perguntas iniciais e explorat√≥rias. Para uma vers√£o completa deste exerc√≠cio de mapeamento, veja Becoming RAD! (publicado em 2021) ou entre em contato com a nossa equipe.

P4: Como posso garantir que as ferramentas tecnol√≥gicas e os dados que estamos usando s√£o realmente √∫teis para o nosso trabalho?

Em nosso trabalho de apoio a organiza√ß√µes da sociedade civil, frequentemente nos deparamos com suposi√ß√µes de que digital significa melhor e que qualquer solu√ß√£o tecnol√≥gica levar√° a maior efici√™ncia, efic√°cia e impacto.

Mas nem sempre √© assim. Quando estamos trabalhando mais intensamente com um parceiro, frequentemente come√ßamos com uma avalia√ß√£o de como seu uso de tecnologia e dados s√£o mapeados para seu trabalho e contexto. Isso pode nos ajudar a entender como, ou mesmo se, a forma com que usam a tecnologia est√° fortalecendo seu trabalho.

Depois de mapear quais ferramentas a organiza√ß√£o est√° usando e quais dados s√£o coletados, armazenados e compartilhados, vamos a uma segunda rodada de perguntas: qu√£o √∫til tudo isso √© (ou qu√£o √∫til poderia ser) no contexto do seu trabalho:

Qual √© o principal problema social ou pol√≠tico no qual voc√™ est√° trabalhando? O seu uso de tecnologia e dados est√° lhe auxiliando a lidar com esse problema? Se sim, como? Se n√£o, por que voc√™ acha que isso est√° acontecendo? Seu uso cotidiano de tecnologia e dados est√° lhe auxiliando a se conectar com indiv√≠duos ou institui√ß√µes importantes para o seu trabalho? H√° muito a se pensar na hora de escolher uma ferramenta, e h√° muitas op√ß√µes por a√≠ ‚Äì incluindo v√°rias que voc√™ talvez ainda n√£o conhe√ßa. Ent√£o, como come√ßar a reduzir (ou expandir) as suas op√ß√µes?

Em 2017, com base em uma pesquisa que fizemos sobre escolha de ferramentas em organiza√ß√µes da sociedade civil, criamos um guia interativo para escolha de ferramentas chamado Alidade, que guia as organiza√ß√µes da sociedade civil por meio de perguntas que podem ajud√°-las a decidir que tipo de ferramenta tecnol√≥gica seria adequada para seu projeto ou suas necessidades organizacionais. Recomendamos que voc√™ teste!

Em geral, quando organiza√ß√µes est√£o buscando novas ferramentas tecnol√≥gicas, achamos que as seguintes diretrizes s√£o √∫teis:

Pesquise as pessoas, o problema e, depois, a tecnologia. Analise o problema geral para o qual voc√™ acha que alguma ferramenta tecnol√≥gica poderia ser √∫til. Pense no seu p√∫blico-alvo. Fa√ßa uma pesquisa e considere op√ß√µes diferentes em rela√ß√£o a quais op√ß√µes tecnol√≥gicas est√£o dispon√≠veis. Pense duas vezes antes de criar. Pesquise por ferramentas j√° existentes que possam fazer o que voc√™ precisa. Criar uma ferramenta totalmente nova pode ser mais complexo e arriscado. Obtenha uma segunda opini√£o. Outra pessoa provavelmente j√° tentou uma abordagem parecida antes de voc√™. Encontre essa pessoa e pe√ßa conselhos a ela. Sempre fa√ßa testes. Teste pelo menos duas ferramentas, com as pessoas que voc√™ quer que as usem, antes de escolher. O teste destaca problemas logo no in√≠cio. Tamb√©m levanta quest√µes que voc√™ nunca imaginou que teria. Esteja preparado para o fracasso. Voc√™ n√£o vai acertar de primeira. Tenha or√ßamento separado e se planeje para fazer ajustes regulares √† ferramenta ao longo do projeto. Reflita sobre o que voc√™ est√° fazendo. Tenha sempre em mente o que est√° e o que n√£o est√° funcionando. Aplique o que voc√™ aprender ao trabalho da sua organiza√ß√£o e compartilhe com outras organiza√ß√µes.

Certifique-se de que as ferramentas que voc√™ escolher tamb√©m se adequam √†s suas necessidades de seguran√ßa. Quando estiver avaliando a seguran√ßa de uma ferramenta, considere o seguinte:  

Qual √© a pol√≠tica de privacidade da ferramenta? Que tipo de dados a ferramenta coleta e com quem esses dados s√£o compartilhados? Quem tem acesso a quaisquer dados armazenados na ferramenta? A abordagem da ferramenta em rela√ß√£o √† privacidade e seguran√ßa √© bem documentada? O que voc√™ consegue descobrir sobre os registros de privacidade e seguran√ßa da ferramenta?

Documente e discuta suas descobertas com seus colegas antes de tomar a decis√£o final a respeito de uma ferramenta.

P6: Minha organiza√ß√£o quer integrar novas tecnologias, mas ainda n√£o encontramos a ferramenta certa. Dever√≠amos criar n√≥s mesmos uma ferramenta?

Se voc√™ est√° familiarizado com o nosso trabalho, provavelmente sabe que muitas vezes defendemos a adapta√ß√£o de ferramentas existentes para suas necessidades quando poss√≠vel (chamamos isso de ‚Äúreutiliza√ß√£o de ferramenta‚Äù).

Nossa pesquisa nessa √°rea ao longo dos √∫ltimos anos mostrou que reutilizar e adaptar ferramentas existentes pode ter muitas vantagens, como uso mais eficiente de recursos financeiros e aumento do acesso ao suporte para a implementa√ß√£o e manuten√ß√£o.

Criar uma ferramenta do zero, por outro lado, pode ser um processo custoso e longo que pode levar √† frustra√ß√£o: j√° vimos como ferramentas podem acabar sendo ineficazes ou pouco usadas, ter um custo alto inesperado ou demandar muitos recursos para serem mantidas ou atualizadas.

Mas se simplesmente n√£o consegue encontrar a funcionalidade que a sua organiza√ß√£o est√° buscando e voc√™ est√° considerando criar uma nova ferramenta, aqui est√£o algumas quest√µes sobre as quais refletir:

H√° uma necessidade real e identific√°vel para esta ferramenta? Ela lhe aproximar√° dos seus objetivos de longo prazo? Criar uma ferramenta responderia a uma necessidade intensa que surgiu no seu trabalho ou a ideia surgiu por outros motivos? Voc√™ tem os recursos necess√°rios para criar a ferramenta, mant√™-la a longo prazo e fornecer suporte constante para as pessoas que continuar√£o a us√°-la? Qual √© a sua vis√£o para a ferramenta no longo prazo? As necessidades ou problemas que a ferramenta est√° sendo constru√≠da para atender e resolver podem evoluir ao longo do tempo?

‚Äì Building digital tools in social justice organisations: what to consider before getting started (em ingl√™s)
‚Äì Successful tool re-use in open contracting (em ingl√™s)
‚Äì Don‚Äôt reinvent the wheel, refine it. (em ingl√™s)

Voltar ao in√≠cio

P7. Como posso usar tecnologia/dados se meu acesso √† internet ou √† eletricidade n√£o √© confi√°vel?

Se voc√™ tem dificuldades com acesso intermitente √† internet, considere adotar ferramentas que permitam que voc√™ trabalhe tanto online como offline. Com o Google Docs, por exemplo, voc√™ pode permitir o acesso offline aos documentos. Isso vai permitir que voc√™ continue seu trabalho offline e depois sincronize os documentos quando a conex√£o voltar. Algumas ferramentas de coleta e gerenciamento de dados, como Kobo ToolBox, tamb√©m permitem que voc√™ colete dados nos dispositivos quando n√£o tem conex√£o e depois fa√ßa o upload dos dados no servidor quando a rede estiver dispon√≠vel. Para reuni√µes online em cen√°rios e configura√ß√µes de baixa conectividade, Mumble √© uma op√ß√£o gratuita, leve e de c√≥digo aberto para liga√ß√µes apenas de √°udio.

Se o or√ßamento da sua organiza√ß√£o permitir, tamb√©m recomendamos investir em uma conex√£o de backup; por exemplo, uma conex√£o de rede m√≥vel √† qual conectar seus aparelhos quando sua conex√£o de banda larga n√£o estiver dispon√≠vel.

H√° duas formas de fazer isso: usar um modem de internet m√≥vel ou usar um smartphone dedicado para criar um ponto de acesso ao qual outros aparelhos podem se conectar e compartilhar a conex√£o m√≥vel. Aqui est√° um tutorial r√°pido de como criar um ponto de acesso m√≥vel em um smartphone Android. Voc√™ pode limitar a quantidade de dados usados ao compartilhar a senha de acesso apenas com aparelhos ou usu√°rios essenciais.

Em casos em que a conex√£o √† internet e/ou √† eletricidade √© intermitente e voc√™ est√° trabalhando online, certifique-se de que est√° salvando seu trabalho com a maior frequ√™ncia poss√≠vel para minimizar os riscos de perder trabalho.

Se por quedas de energia com frequ√™ncia, adquirir um gerador como backup pode ser uma op√ß√£o interessante, desde que voc√™ tenha os recursos organizacionais para isso.

Voltar ao in√≠cio

P8. Como trabalho com pessoas desenvolvedoras e/ou especialistas em tecnologia?

H√° muitos tipos diferentes de profissionais com os quais voc√™ pode trabalhar. Tipos comuns de profiss√µes que interagem com tecnologia ou dados incluem:

Design de user experience (UX): Trabalha tanto com clientes (neste caso, √© voc√™!) como usu√°rios para criar um produto que satisfa√ßa necessidades diversas e seja f√°cil de entender e operar. Design gr√°fico: Cuida dos elementos visuais que um site, ferramenta, app ou publica√ß√£o usam e √© respons√°vel por criar a identidade visual (ou branding). Frequentemente trabalha junto com o UX designer para garantir que a identidade visual tamb√©m funciona bem para as pessoas que s√£o usu√°rias. Ilustra√ß√£o: Cria ilustra√ß√µes, √≠cones, infogr√°ficos e mais, que v√£o compor a estrutura maior que o designer gr√°fico e o UX designer criaram. Desenvolvimento front-end:  Implementa o design em um site, ferramenta ou app. Em particular, √© capaz de programar os aspectos que os usu√°rios v√£o ver e com os quais v√£o interagir. Desenvolvimento back-end: Desenvolve e conecta um banco de dados ao front-end (as partes do site, app ou ferramenta que um usu√°rio pode ver) e faz todas as tarefas n√£o vis√≠veis que preencher√£o o front-end com conte√∫do din√¢mico. An√°lise/Ci√™ncia de dados: Extrai padr√µes de grandes volumes de dados. Tamb√©m pode estar equipado com as ferramentas e o conhecimento necess√°rios para criar visualiza√ß√µes de dados a fim de comunicar padr√µes importantes. Sysadmin/DevOps: Mant√©m os servidores onde ficam o site, as ferramentas ou apps. Frequentemente √© respons√°vel por coordenar a identifica√ß√£o e solu√ß√£o de problemas se as usu√°rias encontrarem bugs ou erros.

√Äs vezes, as fun√ß√µes podem se justapor: por exemplo, voc√™ pode contratar uma pessoa que lidera o design e desenvolvimento de um site, ou uma pessoa desenvolvedora que √© capaz de trabalhar tanto em front-end como em back-end.

Antes de contratar desenvolvedores e especialistas em tecnologia, √© √∫til:

Ter clareza do porqu√™ voc√™ quer criar ou adaptar novas ferramentas. Identificar os recursos que voc√™ tem e dos quais vai precisar. Lembrar-se de se planejar para manuten√ß√£o a longo prazo.

No in√≠cio de seu trabalho juntos, √© importante estabelecer pontos em comum e uma terminologia compartilhada a respeito das necessidades e expectativas. Recomendamos criar um Termo de Refer√™ncia  para documentar e compartilhar necessidades e exig√™ncias do projeto. O Termo de Refer√™ncia deve abordar, no m√≠nimo:

O or√ßamento dispon√≠vel para o projeto  O prazo necess√°rio Seus objetivos Suas expectativas em rela√ß√£o ao parceiro externo Quaisquer informa√ß√µes adicionais

Voc√™s tamb√©m devem chegar a um acordo em rela√ß√£o a ferramentas, canais de comunica√ß√£o, fun√ß√µes e responsabilidades. 

Tudo isso pode contribuir muito para o sucesso do projeto desde o in√≠cio. Algumas coisas que voc√™ deve fazer ao trabalhar com consultores, uma vez que o trabalho est√° em andamento, s√£o:

Perguntas relacionadas:

P9. Minha organiza√ß√£o faz muito de seu trabalho online, mas nossa colabora√ß√£o nem sempre corre t√£o bem. Como podemos fazer para que a colabora√ß√£o online funcione melhor para n√≥s?

Sabemos em primeira m√£o que, quando se trata de colaborar online, encontrar a maneira certa de se comunicar √© essencial ‚Äì tanto para que o trabalho corra bem como para o bem-estar geral.

Idealmente, sua equipe ter√° uma sele√ß√£o de ferramentas ou canais para usar (por exemplo, um mix de apps de chat, e-mail e ferramentas de gerenciamento de projetos seguros), mas √© importante que cada um deles tenha uma fun√ß√£o clara.

Com frequ√™ncia, as organiza√ß√µes com quem trabalhamos  usam tantas ferramentas diferentes que se sentem sobrecarregados toda vez que precisam compartilhar um documento, ideia ou mensagem. Se este for o caso da sua organiza√ß√£o, separe um tempo para listar rapidamente todas as ferramentas diferentes que as pessoas usam para se comunicar ‚Äì a lista pode incluir apps como Signal e WhatsApp, plataformas de mensagens como Slack e Mattermost, CRMs online como Salesforce, ferramentas VOIP como Skype, Zoom ou Jitsi Meet, e ferramentas colaborativas como Trello, Air Table, Asana e outras. Talvez voc√™ tamb√©m use mensagens SMS ou liga√ß√µes por telefone.

Quando tiver essa lista em m√£os, sugerimos que se re√∫na com as pessoas com as quais voc√™ mais colabora e entrem em um acordo para tentar usar menos ferramentas. D√™ um prop√≥sito espec√≠fico a cada ferramenta: por exemplo, talvez e-mail seja para mensagens mais longas e que n√£o sejam t√£o urgentes, ou para compartilhar documentos, enquanto programas de mensagens s√£o para quest√µes urgentes ou conversas casuais.

Quando tiver identificado algumas coisas que funcionam, documente! O registro garantir√° que todos est√£o na mesma p√°gina e ser√° uma √≥tima refer√™ncia para pessoas novas que entrarem na equipe ou simplesmente para servir de lembrete dos processos/projetos.

Voltar ao in√≠cio Seguran√ßa e cuidado em foco P10: Como posso garantir que toda minha equipe est√° usando as ferramentas (ou processos de dados) que escolhemos?

Mesmo quando estamos animados com uma nova ferramenta ou processo tecnol√≥gico para usar dados, de fato adotar novos modos de trabalho √© dif√≠cil. Ao mesmo tempo, garantir que estamos usando as ferramentas acordadas (e seus protocolos e seguran√ßa ou prote√ß√£o relevantes) √© uma maneira importante atrav√©s da qual podemos praticar o cuidado um com o outro nas organiza√ß√µes.

Um passo a ser tomado para ajudar todos a adotar uma nova forma de trabalho √© garantir que a nova ferramenta ou o novo protocolo respondam a uma necessidade concreta e que todos saibam qual ela √©. Isso significa que todos sabem que, ao se esfor√ßar para aprender a usar a nova ferramenta, estar√£o mais pr√≥ximos da solu√ß√£o de um problema que v√™m enfrentando.

Ao mesmo tempo, √© importante gerenciar as expectativas ‚Äì as mudan√ßas podem ser sentidas pouco a pouco, ao longo do tempo, conforme mais pessoas usam uma ferramenta ou um protocolo e se familiarizam com ela/ele. Isso faz parte do processo.

E, porque √© um processo, √© bom dar espa√ßo e tempo para aprendizado, adapta√ß√£o e discuss√£o quando uma nova ferramenta √© selecionada. Dependendo do que mais estiver acontecendo, as capacidades para aprender algo novo podem variar entre as equipes, e dar espa√ßo pode ser a melhor forma de reconhecer isso.

Por fim, ouvir as experi√™ncias das pessoas que est√£o usando a nova ferramenta pode lhe ajudar a identificar maneiras que voc√™ pode ajustar a pr√≥pria ferramenta, se for poss√≠vel, ou ajustar como ela vem sendo aplicada.

P11: O que podemos fazer para manter as pessoas em seguran√ßa quando come√ßarmos a usar diferentes ferramentas tecnol√≥gicas e pr√°ticas de dados?

Muitas das pessoas com quem conversamos est√£o curiosas a respeito de como podem incorporar a seguran√ßa e o cuidado em todo o trabalho que fazem ‚Äì especialmente quando se trata de novas iniciativas tecnol√≥gicas e de dados. Ao vermos nos notici√°rios, nas nossas comunidades e em nossas pr√≥prias experi√™ncias situa√ß√µes como vazamentos de dados e ferramentas hackeadas, pode parecer desafiador adotar ferramentas ou processos tecnol√≥gicos com seguran√ßa.

Uma abordagem que pode auxiliar a fornecer uma base √© a de Responsible Data (ou ‚Äúdados respons√°veis‚Äù, em uma tradu√ß√£o livre): a ideia de que compartilhamos um ‚Äúdever coletivo de prestar contas das consequ√™ncias n√£o intencionais de trabalhar com dados‚Äù.

Algumas √°reas a serem exploradas e que est√£o sob o guarda-chuva dos dados respons√°veis s√£o:

Pr√°ticas como minimiza√ß√£o de dados (apenas coletar os dados que voc√™ precisa). Conceitos como consentimento (certificar-se de que as pessoas s√£o capazes de concordar de maneira livre, espec√≠fica, informada e revog√°vel com como seus dados ser√£o usados). Espa√ßos relacionados, como seguran√ßa organizacional (uma rica √°rea de pr√°tica em torno da defini√ß√£o de protocolos que podem auxiliar a criar seguran√ßa de dados/informa√ß√µes e bem-estar f√≠sico e seguran√ßa). 

Se voc√™ n√£o est√° familiarizado com esses tipos de pr√°ticas, h√° alguns recursos que podem ajudar ‚Äì desde guias online at√© suporte do praticante.

Escolher ferramentas que priorizem sua seguran√ßa pode ser outro passo a ser dado. Com frequ√™ncia, essas ferramentas n√£o s√£o t√£o utilizadas como suas contrapartes menos seguras, ent√£o essa pode ser uma oportunidade para consultar colegas com pensamento similar ou contatar um especialista em tecnologia externo em quem voc√™ confie. Algumas dessas ferramentas podem incluir:

Gerenciadores de senhas: Criar senhas fortes e exclusivas √© uma parte fundamental ao usar a tecnologia com mais seguran√ßa. Gerenciadores de senha podem tanto acompanhar suas senhas usadas como ajud√°-lo a criar senhas fortes. Saiba mais aqui. Ferramentas de comunica√ß√£o mais seguras: Muitas das mensagens que enviamos digitalmente n√£o s√£o criptografadas, o que significa que, se algu√©m tentar intercept√°-las, poderia ler o conte√∫do. Ferramentas de comunica√ß√£o mais seguras oferecem criptografia, tornando mais dif√≠cil que pessoas leiam o conte√∫do de suas mensagens. Voc√™ pode aprender mais aqui, ou entrar em contato conosco para aux√≠lio a respeito de ado√ß√£o de novas ferramentas. Redes privadas virtuais: Uma VPN (virtual private network, em ingl√™s) √© uma ferramenta que pode ajudar a proteger sua atividade na web contra vigil√¢ncia na rede de internet que voc√™ est√° usando. Escolher a VPN certa ‚Äì e conhecer suas limita√ß√µes ‚Äì √© crucial, e depende do contexto no qual voc√™ est√° inserido (em qual pa√≠s est√°, qual VPN escolheu etc.). Ao mesmo tempo, escolher a VPN certa para a sua situa√ß√£o pode ser complexo, ent√£o se informe mais aqui e n√£o hesite em entrar em contato conosco para obter ajuda.

Sempre tenha em mente que seguran√ßa √© uma mistura tanto de ferramentas como de pr√°ticas. √â importante ter as ferramentas corretas, mas √© igualmente importante us√°-las do jeito correto e construir pr√°ticas internas fortes quando o assunto for seguran√ßa em geral, levando em considera√ß√£o seguran√ßa f√≠sica e psicol√≥gica tamb√©m.
